awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Structure, Dynamics, and Mechanism B program supports the research of Professor Joseph P. Dinnocenzo at the University of Rochester. Professor Dinnocenzo and his students investigate novel exciplexes (excited state complexes), especially cationic (positively charged) exciplexes. The research activities provide foundational knowledge about electron transfer and new types of exciplexes.  Substances which form exciplexes have potential applications as sensors, as biological probes, and in organic light emitting diodes (OLED). Due to their solubility in water, cationic exciplexes have enhanced potential for development of biological imaging applications. The research provides a rich educational experience for undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students, in  synthesis, electrochemistry and time-resolved spectroscopy. This research specifically engages undergraduates from the University of Guam (a minority institution in the US Territory) for summer research opportunities.  This group is underrepresented in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM).

This project investigates two types of novel, charge transfer exciplex intermediates that were recently discovered in the Dinnocenzo laboratory. One type of exciplex is formed by reaction of cationic, excited state acceptors with neutral donors. Research objectives include determining the electronic nature of the exciplexes (e.g. electronic coupling matrix elements) through theoretical fitting of radiative lifetimes, which are determined by Time Correlated Single Photon Counting (TCSPC) and fluorescence spectra. This project expands the generality of cationic exciplexes by measuring some of their photophysical properties, examining cationic exciplexes in a variety of media (including water), and synthesizing intramolecular examples. A related project investigates examples uncovered in the Professor Dinnocenzo's lab where two exciplex emissions are observed from a single acceptor and donor. Preliminary results are consistent with dramatically different solvent reorganization energies for the two types of exciplexes, indicating major differences in their structures. In this research, students learn how to synthesize, purify, and spectroscopically characterize compounds. Students also receive training in a range of less traditional techniques including transient absorption spectroscopy (TCSPC), fluorometry, electrochemistry, and modern computational chemistry. The students trained through the research are prepared to tackle a variety of multidisciplinary problems in their professional careers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The properties of newly discovered emissive cationic exciplexes (excited state complexes) were explored.  Exciplexes are key intermediates in a wide variety of photoinduced charge transfer processes, including intra- and intermolecular electron transfers in solution and in biological systems (e.g. DNA and photosynthetic reaction centers).  Emissive exciplexes have also found applications as sensors to probe biological systems. There has recently been an explosion of interest in exciplexes in organic light emitting diodes (OLEDs, e.g. new high efficiency OLED materials based on thermally activated delayed fluorescence) and in photovoltaic materials.

Since their discovery nearly 50 years ago, it was long thought that organic exciplexes could only formed between neutral electron acceptors and donors.  Recent research in the PI's lab has shown that emissive exciplexes can also be formed between cationic electron acceptors and neutral electron donors.  This discovery opens up potential new avenues for applications of exciplexes.  For example, we have shown that strongly emissive cationic exciplexes can be formed in water.  Besides their strong emission, the cationic exciplexes were found to have a number of interesting properties, including a strong temperature dependence of the emission strength and the emission wavelength on solvent polarity that is markedly different from conventional exciplexes formed between neutral electron acceptors and donors.  Research on the solvent polarity of exciplex emissions led to an unexpected discovery that the solvent polarity function long used to correlate with exciplex emission wavelength has serious limitations.  These results will hopefully stimulate new theoretical research efforts to find better solvent polarity models that can be used to model exciplex emission.

The grant has provided training opportunities for a range of students:  undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral. Students learn an especially broad set of skills.  For example, the research project requires students to synthesize, purify, and characterize new molecules using modern techniques and spectroscopy. Students also learn less traditional methodologies, such as electrochemistry, steady-state photolysis, fluorometry, transient absorption spectroscopy, and time-correlated single photon counting.  This broad training prepares students well to be independent scientists in a range of scientific fields.

 


Last Modified: 11/29/2022
Modified by: Joseph P Dinnocenzo
